abstract.p: In this article, lattice Boltzmann model (LBM) was used as a numerical method for microchannel flow simulation. Slip flow regime for which Knudsen number varies from 0.1 to 1.0 was investigated using an effective mean free path in relaxation-time-parameter of LBM. Computations were performed for pressure-driven and shear flow configurations of a microchannel. Nonlinear flow characteristics of Knudsen layer were captured in shear flow regime along with the phenomenon of slip length. The slip velocity was predicted in both flow configurations with good accuracy. For pressure-driven flow geometry, velocity distribution across the channel showed better correspondence with that of direct simulation Monte Carlo (DSMC) method for Knudsen numbers less than 0.5, as compared to those obtained from Navier–Stokes equations and conventional LBM simulation. While discrepancies were observed between present results and those of DSMC for Knudsen numbers greater than 0.5, present computations showed improved velocity profile as compared to Navier–Stokes and conventional LBM simulations.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Microscale gas flows have received much attention particularly due to rapidly emerging technology of micro-electronic-Mechanical-System (MEMS) [1–3] and the need of studying flow through them. Two main characteristics of the flow in MEMS are having low mach number and nonzero Knudsen number, which is defined as the ratio of mean free path, λ, to the characteristic length of the physical domain, H. Low-speed gaseous flow in micro-devices has large Knudsen numbers in the range of slip (0.001 < Kn < 0.1 ) or transition flow (0.1 < Kn < 10 ), which are far from thermodynamic equilibrium. The Navier–Stokes equations with no-slip boundary condition are applicable to flows with Kn < 0.001 while Boltzmann Equation (BE) is valid for flows with arbitrary Knudsen number. On the other hand, the numerical solution of BE is a time-consuming process especially for the most accurate one which iscalled direct simulation Monte Carlo (DSMC) method [4]. Moreover, this method is suitable for high-speed transition flows, a situation never exist in microchannel flows.

Gas microflow experiences some non-equilibrium phenomena, among them are velocity slip and temperature jump at the solid walls and a nonlinear stress-strain relationship within the Knudsen layer, which is a region near a solid wall with a thickness of a few mean free path. Navier–stokes equations with slip flow velocity boundary layer are able to predict microchannel flows in slip flow regime [2]. Lattice Boltzmann model (LBM), which is a numerical method derived from BE, is a relatively new and effective numerical approach in simulating fluid flows [5–7]. LBM has greater potential to model non-equilibrium flows with non-zero Knudsen number due to its kinetic nature originated in BE. Moreover, LBM has some major advantages as compared to other methods in fluid flow simulations such as implementation of fully parallel algorithms and computationally efficient and accurate method. It was shown that LBM is able to simulate flows in microchannels for a range of Knudsen numbers up to the transition flow regime [8, 9]. Although transition flow regime was investigated by some authors [10, 11], prediction of nonlinear stress-strain relationship still remains a challenge in modeling such flow regimes.

Various authors studies microchannel flows through LBM. Guo et al.[8] studied the physical symmetry, spatial accuracy, and relaxation time of the lattice Boltzmann equation (LBE) for microgas flows in both slip and transition regimes. They indicated that for a microgas flow, the channel wall confinement exerts a nonlinear effect on the relaxation time, which should be considered in the LBE for modeling microgas flows. Such treatment can improve the accuracy of LBE for simulating microgas flows with a relatively large Knudsen number. Niu et al. [11] provided a systematic description of the kinetic LBM, including LBE and definition of the relaxation time to capture the nonlinear effects due to the high-order moments and wall boundaries. They used an effective relaxation time and a modified regularisation procedure of the non-equilibrium partof the distribution function based on previous works [8, 12]. They investigated micro-flows such as Couette and force-driven Poiseuille flows for a range of Knudsen number using an effective mean free path, which was proposed by Guo et al.[8].

Zhang et al. [10] used an effective mean free path toaddress the Knudsen layer effect, resulting in anextension of the capabilities of LBM beyond the slip flow regime. Their results showed that the proposed approach significantly improves the near-wall accuracy of the lattice Boltzmann method for planar Couette flow up to Kn = 1.0 , but it was not the casefor pressure-driven flow. For the latter case, thewall-function approach provided a significant improvement for Knudsen numbers up to 0.5, but the method was unable to capture the full effect of the Knudsen layer for Kn > 0.5 . Some authors have investigated the relation between slip length and Knudsen number, among them is the work of Bhattacharya and Lie [13, 14]. They suggested a logarithmic dependence of slip length on Knudsen number.

The present work focuses on the application of aneffective mean free path proposed by Zhang et al. [10] for slip and transition flow regimes in microchannel flow. Two common flow configurations in microchannels, namely shear and pressure-driven flows, are discussed using effective mean free path. The nonlinear flow characteristics of the Knudsen layer are captured in shear flow regime. The phenomenon of slip length is studied using LBM with effective mean free path. Moreover, the range of Knudsen numbers studied in the present work are extended beyond those that have been previously studied.

Application of LBM in microchannel flow simulation needs special attention due to the phenomena of Knudsen layer, determination of the effective relaxation time, τ , and boundary conditions. A brief discussion of each of these phenomena is presented here along with their computational procedure.

sec.title: 3.1 Knudsen layer
sec.p: A key non-dimensional parameter for gas microflow is Knudsen number, which is defined as the ratio of the mean free path λ to the characteristic length, H, of the flow configuration as (8)

Rarefaction effect becomes more important as theKnudsen number increases. A fluid flow can be considered as continuum for Kn ≤, 10−3 and free-molecular flow for Kn ≥ 10 . A rarefied gas can be considered neither an absolutely continuous medium nor a free-molecular flow. It covers a range of Knudsen numbers between 10− 3 and 10. This region is divided into two parts, that is, slip flow (10 − 3} < Kn < 0.1) and transition flow regimes (0.1 < Kn < 10) , see Fig. 2. Fig. 2
Knudsen number regimes

Knudsen layer (or kinetic boundary layer) is a region near a solid wall with a thickness of a few mean free paths, where the usual linear relationship between the stress and rate of strain is no longer valid. Figure 3 shows schematically the Knudsen layer. Solid line in this figure shows the structure of the Knudsen layer within a shear flow bounded by a planar wall. In this region, the gas is far from a state of local thermodynamic equilibrium. For many flow situations, the scale of the Knudsen layer is negligible in comparison to the macroscopic length scale of interest. However, for Knudsen numbers greater than about 0.01, Knudsen layer starts to impact on the entire flow field. A slip-boundary condition is used in Navier–Stokes equations for simulating Knudsen-layer effects [2]. However, the slip velocity obtained from this boundary condition is not the actual velocity slip that occurs at the gas surface interface as is observed in Fig. 3. Knudsen layer becomes a significant proportion of the flow field for high Knudsen numbers, where the Navier–Stokes equations would not be appropriate. Fig. 3
Schematic diagram showing the Knudsen layer. real velocity profile( solid line), velocity profile obtained by Navier-Stokes (dashed line)

Knudsen layer will have a significant impact on the distance a gas molecule can travel between successive collisions through the presence of a solid wall. As a consequence, the mean free path will be smaller than that observed in the bulk flow for near-wall region. Some authors used an effective mean free path [8, 10] in their computations, which is defined as the average distance a gas molecule will travel between consecutive collisions with either another gas molecule or the solid wall.

sec.title: 3.3 Boundary conditions
sec.p: Capturing slip flow in microchannels is done through appropriate boundary conditions. Different boundary conditions have been developed to capture velocity slip at the wall, for example, bounce back, specular reflection and a combination of the these two [21], kinetic boundary condition [22], a virtual-wall collision scheme [23] and the Maxwellian kinetic boundary condition considering tangential momentum accommodation coefficient [22, 24]. A commonly used boundary condition, called diffuse-scattering boundary condition (DSBC), was proposed by Niu et al. [25, 26], which is obtained from the well-known Maxwell hypothesis [27]. sec.title: 3.4 Slip length (for Poiseuille flow)
sec.p: Fluid velocity near-wall is not equal to the wall velocity in microchannel flow even if the wall is perfectly thermalising. Existence of velocity slip was first predicted by Maxwell [28]. Its effect is important inmicroscopic flow and in rarefied gas flow. Using the method of molecular dynamics (MD), Bhattacharya and Lie [13, 14] reported a significant reduction in the expected slip length for large Knudsen numbers (Kn > 0.05) . Their analysis employed a hard-sphere gas molecule concept in the definition of mean free path. They suggested that the slip coefficient may vary as ls ∝ ln (Knh) , where Knh is the Knudsen number based on mean free path λh , in a hard-sphere gas.

They reported that the apparent breakdown of the Maxwell theory at the large Knudsen numbers may be due to the importance of the higher-order velocity derivatives or to the coupling with the temperature gradient, which has been neglected in the derivation of Equation (18). Morris et al. [34] reproduced Bhattacharya and Lie's results [13] using Knh and extended the range of Knudsen number to lower number values. They found good agreement with Equation (19) for Kn < 0.05 , however for higher Knudsen number their results were very close to Bhattacharya and Lie's data [13]. Morris et al. [34] employed the following definition for the mean free path, suggested by Cercignani [27] (21)

Here ρ is the fluid density, m is the mass of the particles, T is the temperature, kB is Boltzmann's constant, and η is the viscosity of a hard-sphere gas. They found that the slip length is accurately given by Maxwell theory for the entire range of Knudsen number. They reported α = 0.97 for the slip coefficient. Relation between nondimensional slip length and Knudsen number was obtained through Lattice Boltzmann method in the present computations. The wall effect on the mean free path was also considered in the simulation. The computed results are discussed in the next section.

sec.title: 4 RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
sec.p: A two-dimensional pressure-driven Poiseuille flow and a planar Couette flow are studied for a range of Knudsen numbers using LBM with an effective relaxation time introduced in the previous section. Before discussing the characteristics of these flow configurations, results obtained for slip length is discussed at first.

Figure 5(a) shows variation of nondimensional slip length versus Knudsen number. As is observed in this figure, the present computations are in relatively good agreement with those obtained from Maxwell prediction even for higher Knudsen numbers, while those of Bhattacharya and Lie [13, 14] fails to follow Maxwell prediction at high Knudsen numbers, which may be as a result of neglecting the effect of distance between the walls in their analysis. Morris et al.'s data [34] and the Maxwell theoretical analysis with α = 1.15 are shown in Fig. 5(b). As is observed in this figure, the conventional LBM (without consideringeffective mean free path) overpredicts the slip length as compared to Maxwell's prediction. It is apparent that as a result of using LBM with effective mean free path, our results yield linear relationshipbetween ls and Knudsen number, a behaviour observed in Maxwell's theory. Moreover, the computed data are in good agreement with those of Morris et al. [34]. A least-square fit of our data leads to the value α = 0.94 for the slip coefficient, which is close to the one obtained by Morris et al. [34]. The mean free path based on hard-sphere definition that was used by Bhattacharya and Lie [13, 14], took into account the density and the diameter of the particles. However, it seems that the distance between the walls in a microchannel should also affect the mean free path, since the effective viscosity decreases with increasing Knudsen number. Maxwell theory was originally formulated for the semi-infinite geometry, that is, a fluid bounded by a single wall. It should not be surprising that the theory needs some modification when there is a second boundary nearby [34]. Fig. 5(a)

sec.title: 4.1 Pressure-driven Poiseuille flow
sec.p:
The first flow geometry considered in the present computations was pressure-driven Poiseuille flow in a two dimensional microchannel of height Ohwada et al. [35] found an accurate numerical solution of the Poiseuille flow between two parallel plates on the basis of the linearized BE for hard-sphere molecules, under the assumption of small pressure gradient or incompressible flow. A uniform pressure gradient was applied in the streamwise direction, along with periodic boundary condition in this direction. Three uniform grid sizes of 33 × 33, 55 × 55, 85 × 85 were used for present computations to investigate the effect of number of grid points. Results are given in Fig. 6 along with those obtained by Ohwada et al. [35]. It is observed that increasing the number of grid points from 33 × 33 to 85 × 85 does not change the normalized velocity profiles for Knudsen numbers of 0.113 and 0.677. However, the number of grid points used in the present computation was selected as 55 × 55 to retain both accuracy and high computational speed. Fig. 6
Normalized velocity profiles for pressure-driven Poiseuille flows at different Knudsen numbers and grid sizes obtained by the modified LBE approaches

Figure 7 illustrates normalized velocity profiles, U = u/Uavr (Uavr is the average velocity in the channel), across the channel for various Knudsen numbers. As observed from these figures, velocity profiles obtained with normal LBM (D2Q9 LBM, without using effective mean free path) is similar to those obtained from Navier–Stokes slip flow solutions. Discrepancies between these results and Ohwada et al. [35], which are observed clearly in these figures, increases with increasing Knudsen number. Implementation of LBM with effective mean free path leads to a significant improvement in the results. As is shown in this figure, increasing Knudsen numbers increases slip-velocity at channel walls. Slip-velocity prediction from the present computations is very close to those obtained from Ohwada et al. [35]. Fig. 7

It was reported that LBE model is capable of obtaining Knudsen number for minimum mass flow [36]. sec.title: 4.2 Planar Couette flow
sec.p:
The second flow geometry considered is a planar Couette flow confined between two parallel plates. The upper plate moves with a constant velocity Uw = 0.05 and the lower plate remains stationary. DSBC, which were discussed before, is implemented to describe the gas-surface interactions on the walls. Periodic boundary conditions are also considered in flow direction. Simulations were done for three different uniform grid sizes of 21 × 21, 41 × 41 and 81 × 81, respectively. The normalized velocity profiles U = u/Uw as a function of distance between two walls (Y = y/H ) are observed in Fig. 9 for Knudsen numbers of 0.1 and 1.0. As is observed in this figure, increasing the number of grid points does not change the computed velocity profile. A 41 × 41 grid points were used for present computations. Fig. 9
Normalized velocity profiles for planar Couette flows at different Knudsen numbers and grid sizes

Figure 10 illustrates Knudsen layer phenomenon in transition regime. Four Knudsen numbers of 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, and 1.0 were considered in these figures. The most accurate velocity profile available is that obtained from DSMC method [38], which is shown in these figures. Slip velocities on the walls computed from DSMC method are obviously observed for these Knudsen numbers. Figure 11 shows variation of the normalized slip velocity (uw − uf)/uw with Knudsen number for micro-Couette flow. It is apparent that the magnitude of slip velocity increases with increasing Knudsen number. As a result of using LBM with effective relaxation time, significant improvement invelocity profile was obtained as compared to conventional LBM (D2Q9 LBM, without using effective mean free path). The non-linear behaviour of velocity profile in Knudsen layer was captured using present LBM with effective mean free path. It is concluded that implementation of LBM with effective mean free path improves the accuracy of LBM in predicting the flow characteristics in planar Couette flow significantly. Fig. 10

sec.title: 5 CONCLUSION
sec.p: Microchannel flow was investigated using LBM with effective mean free path. The reason for using such effective mean free path was to extend the capabilityof normal LBM beyond the slip flow regimes in micro-channels. Moreover, this implementation hasa significant effect on capturing Knudsen-layer effects in micro-flow simulations. This approach is based on the implementation of the effect of walls on the mean free path. Results showed that the method is able to predict flow behaviour with good accuracy in planar Couette flow for Knudsen numbers up to one. However, computational results for pressure-driven channel flow showed the ability of the method in predicting flow characteristics for Kundsen numbers less than 0.5; discrepancies with available accurate data are observed for Kn > 0.5. The phenomenon of slip length is studied using LBM with effective mean free path. Present work extends the range of Knudsen numbers that have been previously studied. By a simple redefinition of the mean free path, good agreement between simulation result and Maxwell theory was obtained for slip length.
